monogr.title: A most excellent and learned vvoorke of chirurgerie, called Chirurgia parua Lanfranci : Lanfranke of Mylayne his briefe: reduced from dyuers translations to our vulgar or vsuall frase, and now first published in the Englyshe prynte by Iohn Halle chirurgien. Who hath thervnto necessarily annexed. A table, as wel of the names of diseases and simples with their vertues, as also of all other termes of the arte opened. ... And in the ende a compendious worke of anatomie ... An historiall expostulation also against the beastly abusers, both of chyrurgerie and phisicke in our tyme: with a goodly doctrine, and instruction, necessary to be marked and folowed of all true chirurgie [n] s. All these faithfully gathered, and diligently set forth, by the sayde Iohn Halle
monogr.author: Lanfranco, of Milan

opener.salute: vnto the yonge studentes of Chirurgerie, and to all the louing readers sendeth greting, begynnyng first with this sentence of the diuyne phylosophier Socrates.

q.l: He that will seke, and knoweth not
Howe muche in more or lesse,
Can neuer tell whan he doth finde,

div.p: THerfore Galen, the Prince of phisiciens, in the .vi. boke of his therapeulike methode affirmeth, that Chirurgiens being ignorant of the Anatomie, may erre in many thinges, specially in their incisions. For (sayth he) if they knew what vnitie and combination the members of the body haue one with an other, & howe they procede: If hurte happen vnto thē, thei might perceiue whether the nerues, or other mēbers hauing proper office or nedfull action be cut or not: and so to iudge truly of their worke, and to be certeyne in theyr incisions.

To the confirmation of whiche sentence, Henricus de Ermunda villa, compareth the chirurgien ignorant in Anatomy, to a blynde mā whiche would hewe a pece of tymber: For as a blynd man, that heweth on a logge, knoweth not howe muche he should hewe therof, nor in what maner, (and therfore commonly erreth, in hewyng more or lesse then he ought to doe:) so lykewyse doth the chyrurgien that worketh on the body of mā, not knowing the Anatomy. And that it is of necessitie, the chirurgien to knowe the Anatomie, the sayde Henry approueth by an euident argument: for euery workeman (sayeth he) should knowe the subiect of his worke. But the subiect of chirurgerie is the body of man, whiche therfore ought to be knowne of the chirurgien. Whiche knowledge of mans body or any part therof, can no wayse be attained but by Anatomie.

Anatome so called of the grecians is sayth Carolus Stephanus, the dissection of man his body, by reason and iudgement, administred as as well in the symple partes as in the cōpounde, to the perfect knowledge of them. For truly, the perfect knowledge of partes doth chiefly consiste in indagacion or diligent exquisition, of substance, quantitie, forme, number, situation and connexion.
